AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
National Weather Service Albany NY
729 AM EDT Thu Sep 5 2024

.SYNOPSIS...
High pressure will bring dry conditions through Friday. Skies 
will be mostly clear, although some patchy low clouds and fog 
will develop late tonight into Friday morning. A slow moving 
frontal system tracking from west to east will bring a period of
rain Saturday afternoon and night, followed by breezy and 
unseasonably cool temperatures for Sunday into early next week.

&&

.NEAR TERM /UNTIL 6 PM THIS EVENING/...
.UPDATE...As of 630 AM EDT, patchy fog has developed within many
river valleys across the region, some of which was locally
dense. This fog will dissipate between 8 and 10 AM.

Otherwise, forecast on track. Temps have dropped into the
lower/mid 40s across the southern Adirondacks, with mid 40s to
lower/mid 50s elsewhere.

[PREVIOUS 350 AM]...As of 345 AM EDT, skies remain clear 
outside of some patchy fog/low clouds forming immediately 
adjacent to some rivers/lakes. Temps have dropped into the 
lower/mid 40s across portions of the southern Adirondacks, with 
upper 40s to lower/mid 50s elsewhere.

Any patchy fog should dissipate between 8-10 AM. Otherwise, 
another sunny and warm day ahead, with afternoon high 
temperatures reaching 75-80 for most valley areas and 70-75 
across higher elevations.

&&

.SHORT TERM /6 PM THIS EVENING THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT/...
Generally clear skies this evening, followed by development of
some patchy low clouds/fog after midnight, especially for 
portions of the the Capital Region south and east. Slightly 
milder tonight with more clouds around, with mainly 50s to 
around 60 for lows, although some mid/upper 40s will be possible
across the southern Adirondacks.

Morning low clouds may linger through mid morning within some
river valleys from the Capital Region south and east, otherwise
becoming mostly sunny with afternoon temperatures reaching 75-80
for lower elevations, and 70-75 across higher terrain areas,
with coolest temps possibly across the higher elevations of the
Berkshires due to a slightly cooler maritime airmass influence.

Mainly dry for Friday night despite increasing clouds. Milder
with lows mainly in the 50s to lower 60s.

Occluded front approaches from the west Saturday. There could be
some breaks in the clouds during the morning hours from the
Hudson River Valley into western New England, otherwise becoming
cloudy with a band of light to moderate rain advancing eastward
during the late morning through afternoon hours. Instability
looks meager at this time, so will keep out mention of thunder
for now. However, should enough sunshine occur before the
frontal rainband approaches, then slightly greater instability
and possible thunderstorms might occur. Gusty south to southeast
winds up to 25 mph will be possible ahead of the front,
especially within the Hudson River Valley. Max temps may reach 
the 70s ahead of the front from the Hudson River Valley east 
into western New England, with mainly 60s to the west. Temps 
will likely drop back through the 60s in the afternoon once rain
develops, perhaps even into the 50s for some western areas.

Some lingering showers Saturday evening, mainly across western
New England, otherwise becoming partly cloudy. Some Lake Effect
rain showers may develop across portions of the Mohawk Valley
and SW Adirondacks later at night. Turning cooler with lows in
the 40s to lower 50s.

&&

.LONG TERM /SUNDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY/...
Upper closed low will track just north of our region, along and just 
north of the U.S./Canada border, Sunday, lifting northeast Monday. 
Upper cold pool will track across northwestern and northern areas, 
and with some lake effect moisture, will result in some scattered 
shower activity into the southern Adirondacks. It will be cooler, 
with a gusty west to northwest wind Sunday. Highs in the 60s to 
around 70 with mid 50s to around 60 higher terrain.

Upper low continues to exit east and north and upper heights rise as 
flat upper ridging builds into our region Monday through Wednesday. 
Dry weather and slowly warming temperatures are expected Monday 
through Wednesday. 

Highs Monday in the lower to mid 70s, with 60s in higher terrain. 
Highs Tuesday and Wednesday in the upper 70s to near 80 with around 
70 to lower 70s higher terrain.

&&

.AVIATION /12Z THURSDAY THROUGH MONDAY/...
High pressure in control through tonight. Typical intervals of IFR 
conditions in fog at KGFL and KPSF through about 13Z, and mainly 
BCFG at KALB. The rest the day through this evening, few clouds if 
any with VFR conditions.  More fog may develop at KGFL and KPSF 
tonight.

Winds will be nearly calm through mid morning. Winds become
south at less than 10 Kt mid morning through this afternoon and
diminish this evening to near calm.

Outlook...

Friday Night: No Operational Impact. NO SIG WX.
Saturday: High Operational Impact. Breezy. Likely SHRA.
Saturday Night: Moderate Operational Impact. Chance of SHRA.
Sunday: No Operational Impact. NO SIG WX.
Sunday Night: No Operational Impact. NO SIG WX.
Monday: No Operational Impact. NO SIG WX.

&&
